reviewText:
There seems to be a trend going on about 'hating on this port'. Something being a trend doesn't mean it's right. Let's do some clarifications.


STORY:
The game has a great story, if you don't do your research you'll find an anime story which you may like and not think twice about.  If you're more aware of japanese culture than the average joe, you'll find the hidden meaning behind it and see it for how awesome it really is. It refers many things that we have in our real world and shows it in another light and tries to pass on a message. I love this fact.

Some people say the story is bland and uninspired. Again, stop listening and following the trends. I know it's the norm for people to be sheep but dammit guys, use your head for yourselves already.


GAMEPLAY:
'' IT DOESN'T PLAY ENOUGH LIKE MEGA MAN ''

Come on.... People bash Capcom for being so cliche and non-innovative, rehashing the same things and resources over and over and freakin' over. Now we FINALLY have innovation from a passionate team and you guys spit on it because it's not a copycat of ''Muh Mega Man''.

The gameplay is fresh, new, innovative and exciting and it'll keep you on your toes. If you want that so-wanted Mega Man gameplay, acquire the Dullahan weapon in the game which makes it as close as possible to playing a Mega Man ZX game.


MUSIC
The OST is fantastic, the Stratacombs stage is my favorite song in the entire game by far. It's pretty diverse and epic, you're sure to find tracks you'll like. No complaints when it comes to music.

GRAPHICS
That's .... up for debate. It's a port of a 3DS game and no, I'm not a ''graphics whoare''. Graphics looks exactly like what you'd expect from this type of game and there's bloody nothing wrong with it. They could make HD filters in the future, but it's not like it would 'suddenly' make it a good game, it already is a good game.

DIFFICULTY
YES!  THANK GOD YES! A game that doesn't take us for morons and actually challenges us to bring us to the best of our abilities as players? I'M IN!


The game features a New Game +, A plethora of challenges, an insane replay value, new features like a speed run mode have been added, the game is updated everytime the devs find something worthy of adding and they are HIGHLY RECEPTIVE OF CRITICISM AND CONSUEMR'S CONCERNS! UNLIKE YOUR DEAR CAPCOM BY THE WAY.


Bottom line, the game is freakin' excellent. It's not because it's a ''cool thing'' to hate on this port that you should do it like a mindless sheep, you're disgracing the work of an entirely dedicated team who put effort into this product. The team is listening to the feedback and are at work to fix whatever's wrong with the port. You guys realize they could just leave it be and take our money right? But no, they actually put legit effort.

My only complaints are the following

- Keiji Inafune being the face of Azure Striker Gunvolt as a marketting technique is completely disgraceful. He lost the fan's respect with how horribly Mighty Number 9 was handled and it's an insult to see him in the spotlight instead of our dearly beloved and precious Mr.Takuya Aizu. Please give credit where it's due, specially since Inafune barely did anything on this game (in his own admittance).

- The community is completely ungrateful and even shameful. Because of this, I highly suggest to watch who you're interacting with on the forums. There's a lot of baiters and trolls following the hype train of ''this port sucks'' without having actually played it for themselves or even bought it.

- Game crashes, it happened to me once during a challenge run and I was kind of upset to have lost all my progress I worked so hard for. Bye Bye S-Rank. It only happened once so far though, so it's probably my laptop.

- There are some glitches here and there that haven't been fixed since the 3DS version, I've figured a few well hidden ones that I'm shocked no one else online seems to have found.

- Keyboard controls configuration.... I beg you inti creates, make it more customizable, make the game adapted for customize keyboard controls I'm begging you.

- Unless you wanna learn the awkward default keyboard mapping, I heavily suggest using a controller.

Great game, great product, highly worth its price, insane replay value, plethora of challenges and things to do and items to collect and play for. GOOD GAME! HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!

This is the review after the game is fixed.

It plays a lot like Megaman Zero and Megaman. It does have the Megaman recipe such as dash, climb, shoot and etc

What is different from Megaman is this, the game mechanics reward you for playing very well in game.


Instead of charging, shooting and slashing, you need to tag your enemies and then use your filed of electricity to kill off your enemies. Sure you can kill them by tagging to death. But electricity is the best way to go. You do not get the boss weapon but you get this neat little upgrade.

You can even make your gear (though it iis really only making the game last longer) Think of it as like Megaman Legends where you collect items and made your own gear. The items are hard to get sometimes but it is worth the effort.

The enemies might be a push over at time but the boss are not. There are not grinding your teeth hard but they are the most entertaining boss fight. The boss fight really shines through the game. For example, when the boss used their power (such as Merak using Lazy Laser), you can feel the boss is getting very determined t0 finish your off. You will do whatever it takes to get stop his attack or avoid it at all cost.

Having to hear the awesome music when I reached 1000 Kudos is the thing I been looking so forward too. It force me to be better and it forces me to keep it at that pace because the music is really integrated well into the game. So if you can played a good game, you will feel like you are empowered, become a full blown yangire or unstoppable force which is neat. Think of it as like Carol from Freedom Planet. You worked hard to get her bike and you do your best to keep it

The storyline is good as well. I literally cried when I finished the game after watching the ending.

This game, I take my hats off the people who made this game.

An amazing port all around. Pretty much every issue that has been brought up about the port was fixed relatively quickly. Controls were improved to allow for skill activation with the right analog stick, you can switch screen modes with F5 and hit Esc to leave the game. Pretty much every complaint anyone has had has been addressed and fixed.

In regards to gameplay, its fairly solid as well. You tag enemies with your gun, then shock them with your electric powers. Different guns have different shot patterns and can tag different numbers of enemies, making choosing which one you use in what situation fairly meaningfull most of the time. The short stages lend themselves well to speed running, and since you get materials for crafting by running stages as well as doing challenges, its usually in your best interest to retry stages several times.

Overall I'd say the game is pretty enjoyable overall. The only main downside I can think of is that the additional dialog crops up while you play is fairly distracting, and theres no way to hear it all unless you periodically stop or slow down. Not to mention the fact that the game penalizes you for going too slow with worse scores; the dialog portraits also can block portions of the screen. Which can make boss battles fairly difficult if you're trying to read ANd play. It can be easily disabled, but its a bit of a shame since it can be kinda neat to see the idle chatter.

reviewText:
This game is quite amazing. By Inti Creates, the developers of the Mega Man Zero and ZX games (as well as 9 and 10), this is truly one great experience.

GAMEPLAY
It is very similar to the Mega Man Zero games in terms of mechanics, you can jump, shoot (in auto-fire), dash, wall-jump (you can't slide off walls nor wall-dash though), and something completely new, unleashing electricity (I don't know how it's called). Basically, it creates an electric field around you which hurts enemies around you, and if you shoot an enemy, which creates a lock-on, activating the field will hurt the enemy(ies) massively. There's an energy meter however so that you can't overuse it. It's an incredibely interesting concept, and I love it. It does create a bit of confusion in terms of how it works though, and it does variate the difficulty of the game a bit too much (sometimes it makes it too easy, sometimes too hard).

GRAPHICS
The 2D pixel art they used is amazing and is, once again, very similar to the Mega Man Zero/ZX games. The full-drawn art in cutscenes and dialogue is also incredible. Overall, it's great, no complaints.

AUDIO
Let's make this clear. The soundtrack is AMAZING. Ippo Yamada, the composer of many Mega Man games, including the future Mighty No. 9,  returns to the stage and makes an impressive soundtrack. However, the instruments used in this are a bit irritating in certain situations, but considering how great the music itself is, I think it compensates. I think a re-mastered soundtrack for release would be a good idea, as long as it isn't overly changed. As for the sound effects, they're pretty basic. The voice acting in the English w/ Japanese Voice and Japanese voice settings is very good as well, but I can't judge too much because I don't know Japanese.

STORY
I'll have to give bonus points for the creators in this category. While the story itself is kinda the same as in MM games (bad guy does bad things), the way it is presented is remarkable. It's told in a mature manner, involving actual world problems and such in conversations and stuff. It's great.

LEVEL DESIGN
Not perfect, but still very good. The stages are fair, don't have many cheap deaths, and are overall very fun to play through. Only complaint is that they are a bit short, but that I'll address a little bit later.

DIFFICULTY AND LENGTH
This game is quite difficult, however very forgivable as it has no life system and you have a lot of health before you die. I like that very much. The length though is a bit disapointing. It's too short honestly. I was able to finish it my first time in 6 hours, which isn't that great. I find it kind of annoying that there are only 6 main bosses to choose from instead of 8 like in Mega Man games, which would have made the game longer. I also believe that the stages themselves are a bit short, the first try it takes only up to 10-15 minutes, but after that I can beat them in barely any time at all.

ONE FINAL COMPLAINT...
Now, even though I absolutely love this game, there is one thing, ONE thing that hurts it A LOT. The PC port. To put it simply, it's a mess. The screen is still split (as this was originally released for the 3DS), so it means that a lot of the area is wasted, it just doesn't look good. Thankfully, at least when you're in-stage, only one screen is shown and the HUD is properly placed. Worst of all, not only is there a launcher with this game (which is automatically a red flag), it's a pain to set up, I spent like 30 minutes setting up the thing to work perfectly. There are two sets for the English language, one with voice, one with not. But it doesn't matter because you can still turn the voices off in the voiced one, and it also has in-game conversations, but that again can be turned off so I'm not sure what the deal is. Just keep one set of languages, not two. It also means that you can't play in other languages with voice acting. Another annoyance is that the controller buttons have to be mapped in the launcher, but even then you can still switch controls inside the game, UGH, this is annoying. I heard that they fixed most of the issues since the release, and considering it was released only a few months ago, I'm expecting improvement over the PC port.

VERIDICT
This game is AMAZING. I LOVED IT. The PC port however hurts it quite a lot, and if you can, I highly suggest you buy the 3DS version instead. Haven't played it, but I can bet that it is certainly better than this. So, yeah, amazing game! Good job Inti Creates! Totally recommend you play this as soon as possible.

reviewText:
Inti Creates did a bang up job with this port of the 3DS game.   Its really easy to pick up and play.  It  some good Japanese voice acting to move the plot in a fairly entertanining way.  The stages are well designed.  (The good thing here is spikes aren't  a one-hit kill as in the Megaman Legacy collection)    There is a broad range of challenges to get your competitive juices flowing.  For welcome chance to get  to top of leaderboards.  For those brave enough to try it,  there is also a Speedrun option at the main menu.    Try getting an A or S+ ranking on those missions. Hopefully fortune smiles down on you and your patience will be rewarded.  Inti Creates did a decent job with the English translation.  There were a few hiccups here in the dialogue.  Thankfully, there is nothng that merits a poor attempt at  localization.  Due to the primary language focusing on its core audience of gamers who live in the Land of the Rising Sun  there is no English voice acting.

No love lost there, in fact the Japanese voice actors do a good job adding depth to the cast of characters.  I like how they've mixed in elements of drama, feelings of betrayal, guilt and determination to forge ahead in a world of mistrust and despair.   A few characters do use gruff language at times.  So, I'd be on the lookout for whose in the room with you. If they happen be small and precocious children then you might have some explaining to do later.  As far as swearing/violence  there's nothing that exceeds a PG Disney esque animated feature.  There's some tongue in cheek moments that might fly over your head.

Moving on..  I tip my hat to the team who were inspired to make this game.   Combat is heavy on runnning and gunning, locking on to targetsand frying foes foolish enough to stand in your way,  with your pulsing electric powers.  Yes, thiis is a platformer, but you are free to backtrack on levels until you activate a stage checkpoint.   Which this game merrily sends your way.  Boss fights and mid-boss fights are of the Megaman variety, which test your skills in pattern recognition, but, reward you for besting your opponents by opting to off them with your skills with a flick of Right thumbstick, on the controler layout.   Most if not all enemies can be vanquished by seniding them to oblivion with your Flashfield attack in tow.   And you can recharge your powers but doublie tapping Down on the D-pad, keyboard, etc.

If you like to speedrun and nail every achievement in your Megaman styled action games. Give ASGV a try.

reviewText:
I played the 3DS version and i am glad that it got a PC port. However, be aware that this is practically the 3DS version with dual screen and all. The good news is that on the actual gameplay by default you'll play with the main screen on display, so the double screens will only appear on a few menus. The only true difference is that it has a lot more dialogue than its handheld counterpart, with voices and all and that's something i was really looking for a game we might have to wait a pair of years for the (already confirmed) sequel.

Gunvolt is pretty much Megaman Zero coated with gimmicks. The main character will use electricity to attack and solve some platforms, so while he carries a gun is mostly part of this mechanic. This also includes the main bosses, having patterns to learn yet some will require some thinking to get the best of our options against them. The game overall is short and easy to master, but carries challenges and a true ending to unlock which will length the gameplay. The game might feel linear sometimes but is part of the focus on highscore runs. Challenges and rewards will require you to go as fast as possible, yet the score will get severely punished if you get damaged.

While the 3DS screens might seem a very small flaw, there's a big one added for the PC version. The conversations added during the stages are EXTREMELY intrusive as textboxes occupy literaly half the screen, and that will be your worst enemy if you are facing a boss yet wanna know more about their personalitites (You can remove them with a single button push however, but will also remove voices). I also have a tiny complain as one of the characters being of unkown gender and the 3DS version used Xe/Xem pronouns, and while in here are refered solely by name to keep xyr identity it was a nice touch from the localization team.

Gunvolt is a great game overall. With the Megaman series crumbling to dust and probably the incoming Mighty No9 (At the time this was written atleast), this should be the horse you must bet on to get back that action platforming yet with its own seal of identity.

Okay so, despite having read previous reviews I did give the game a shot and, for the most part this port is definitely playable (and a lot of friggin fun), but not without some flaws that really do need to be addressed in a future patch.

First off, do not use the Full-Screen setup. The devs forgot to add in a Quit option in-game, so unless you're in Windowed Mode you'll have to either use the Alt-F4 Method, or Crtl-Alt-Delete your way out of the game. Secondly, while you CAN in fact edit the 2 Screens with the Alt Key (or by pressing F5 to switch to other Screen Setups), for some dumb reason it just completely resets should you turn the game off and go back to it at a later time. These are really the only offensive things I noticed about this port that need to be fixed.

Other than that, the game still runs as fine as it did on the 3DS version. It is very well possible to edit your controls (only in-game though, but do make sure to set-up on the initial launch screen first), and despite running at only 30 Frames like the original it rarely if ever chokes. The only drawback from the visual department though is that they forgot to properly upscale a lot of the menu images as well as Character Portraits (they look like they were ripped right out of the 3DS version ;;). I also noticed that Load Times are a little longer for some reason ...

In any case, if you've never played this game yet then there's no shame in getting this port. Between this and the 3DS Version, I'd say probably go with the 3DS version first if you already have one ... at least until Inti makes a patch for this game that fixes the issues I just talked about.

reviewText:
When I first started my other YouTube series, Crushing My Backlog, I expected this gaming journey to be an open and shut case of just completing a game, crossing it off my list, and forever forgetting about it. But that’s not the case with Azure Striker Gunvolt,  the 2014 Inti Creates 2D action platformer that absolutely captured my heart and added a unique spin one of my favorite genres. Hey, I’m go ahead and spoil the ending of this review for you – I highly recommend this game. But don’t leave yet, let me tell you why my love for this runs deep.

The game focuses on our hero, Gunvolt, who is one of many people who’ve developed septimal powers known as adepts. You can look at adepts in the same vein as superheroes – people with superhuman abilities, such as, flight, teleportation, or those who can control various elements, like fire, water, or in Gunvolt’s case, electricity. The world is currently a peaceful place, thanks to the Sumeragi Group – although, behind the scenes the group is actually going to great lengths to attempt to experiment and control the world’s adepts.However, Gunvolt’s employer, QUILL, isn’t going to allow that to happen. You see, the QUILL organization is an anti-Sumeragi group that is directed by its founding member Asimov, who like Gunvolt, is an electricity based adept. Gunvolt owes his life to this man, all because Asimov rescued him from a Sumeragi facility where they were performing horrific experiments on him. Now that he’s free, he has dedicated his life to QUILL and taking down the Sumeragi group. Which brings us to the current events where the game opens with our hero held captive by one of Sumeragi’s henchmen. Gunvolt is tasked with locating and assassinating a unique adept named Lumen who’s housed within a young girl named Joule.

Now it’s no surprise that Azure Striker Gunvolt embodies a Mega Man vibe since the Inti Creates team has worked with the series in the past. Mega Man dealt with Doctor Wily’s robot master antics, while Gunvolt has to hunt down seven crazed adepts who’re associated with Nova and the Sumeragi group. You’ll jump, shoot, and dash your way through stages, just like Mega Man, but in the case of Gunvolt it’s completely different. His weapon alone does very minimum damage and it’s used to tag his enemies. You see, destroying enemies efficiently is a two step process where you must first tag the enemy with your weapon and then finish them off with Gunvolt’s flashfield. Enemies can be tagged up to three times and the flashfield damage is amplified with each increased level.  As you progress through the game and defeat bosses you’ll acquire new weapons that make tagging multiple enemies much easier for higher scores and bonuses, which is where this game starts to shine.

Okay, so at the end of each stage, the player is given a letter grade based off of how well they performed during the stage and between stages. Then afterwards, in Gunvolt’s apartment, they can synthesize different gear to aid them in battle. Some of the more rare gear requires you to complete challenges issued by QUILL to obtain hard to find materials. For instance, there’s a pendant that you can equip that makes spikes lethal and removes Gunvolt’s ability to neutralize damage in exchange for some of his electricity meter, otherwise known as EP. But this accessory adds ten percent to the kudos gained – which is an absolute godsend when you’re shooting for S+ ranks. Kudos matter because they are essential for achieving higher scores. As you traverse through a stage you’ll gain kudos for inflicting damage on enemies, but your kudos will reset back to zero if you receive damage – so a solid performance is ideal. The idea behind kudos is to build up as many as you can, then convert them into bonus points by using an attack skill, passing through a checkpoint, destroying an enemy with a special skill, or completing a mission. You can also acquire bonus kudos by destroying targets with a level three tag, eliminating multiple targets simultaneously, or even killing them while in midair.

At its core Azure Striker Gunvolt is a high-speed action platformer with plenty to keep you busy and many options that allow the player to customize their experience. My initial opinion of this game was lukewarm. During my first play-through I kept thinking to myself that the difficulty was way too easy. Health replenishment came from almost every enemy, bosses only took a couple of tries to defeat, zero controllers were thrown, and I never saw a game over screen – something that I am all too familiar with from Mega Man games.  But looking at Gunvolt as if it were a Mega Man game is completely wrong, because at the end of the day Azure Striker Gunvolt is a completely different experience. An experience that focuses on the player’s skill, speed, and scoring. Sure, I’ve been gushing about how amazing this is, but it does suffer from bland level design where exploration is scarce and enemy variation that is rather lacking, but the mechanics and challenges make up for it. You can pick it up on the Nintendo 3DS eShop for $14.99 and there’s also a demo available if you’d like to try it before you buy it. However, I used the Steam version for this review, which I think is identical and also $14.99; but there is no demo available. So if you stumble upon an extra $14 or you catch it on sale, I’d definitely recommend picking it up. I never thought it would capture my heart, but it did and I hope this review helped persuade you to give it a go, too.

This review focuses on the technical aspects of the port.

First of all, I don't have any of the issues other reviewers seem to have. I have an Nvidia card, so that might be making a difference here, but the latest patch should've fixed issues with Radeon cards (patched within 12 hours or so, so a very quick response, unlike a certain other developer *cough*SEJapan*cough*).

I think FPS is limited to 30, but that is not an issue. It's not jerky, there are no frame drops or anything. Maybe the game could be patched to allow 60 FPS, who knows. It'd certainly be a welcome addition.

This a DS port, so you have two screens. But the way they approached is quite novel. You have the main screen which is big enough to be able to play comfortably, and then you have the status screen nestled in the corner. It gives you a quick glance at any information you need without taking up half of the screen. If you want to pause the game, change your equipment and so on, it switches the screens and pauses the action. So you don't actually need to interact with the smaller screen if you don't want to.

My only gripe is that it would be great if you could map shortcuts to your gamepad, since you actually need to use the keyboard or mouse to use certain skills. Perhaps some solution can be found for this.

Basically, if you've ever played Megaman Zero on an emulator, you'll feel right at home here. There's some additional bells and whistles with this port and I think the devs would be open to add small quality-of-life changes here and there, so I'm looking forward to how this port evolves.

At this price point it's a no-brainer, especially if you've been starved for 2D action games in the Megaman Zero style.

reviewText:
ABOUT THE GAME:

For those who haven't played this on the 3DS, Azure Striker Gunvolt is a Mega Man Zero/ZXesque entry by Inti Creates, who made the aforementioned titles with Capcom. Great music, well designed characters, pretty environments and lightning-fast (heh) gameplay. You can take your time and safely make your way through the stages or you can aim for the top score and blaze your way through the enemies - as long as you don't get hit, which will reset your score counter.

Instead of simply shooting enemies, you tag them with your gun (up to three times per enemy) and then zap them with your flashfield. You don't get boss abilities this time around, but you do unlock new weapons which change the way you tag enemies.

Definitely recommended for any Mega Man and/or 2D platformer fan.

ABOUT THE PORT:

I do have some gripes with this port; the biggest one being the absence of any way to natively set the special skills to my controller - I had to use JoyToKey for that. Also, the whole thing with the two screens being kept instead of integrating all of the interface to a single screen does strike me as lazy. Some graphics could use some upscaling as well (mainly the dialogue boxes). I also heard of some people with AMD GPUs having issues with the game, but it seems this has been patched (I did not encounter any issues since I have a GeForce GPU).

That said, I'm still having tons of fun with this port. Using a DualShock 3 will always be more comfortable than a 3DS XL in my opinion, and I'm loving the new dialogue (even though it's coming to the 3DS as well). All in all the 3DS version is still the best one, but if you don't have one, go ahead and get the PC version.

reviewText:
Most of the game is rather awesome, but the boss fights are wayyyy to busy visually, with confusing special effects everywhere that make it very hard to follow what the hell is even going on. Despite this, the game is actually very forgiving: You have lots of health and, under certain conditions, you can even take hits without taking any damage.

However, despite the fact that the game isn't actually hard, you will most likely not feel in control of the situation during several boss fights, making them confusing and a drag to go through.

The stages themselves are mostly a joy to play, but the port is absolutely atrocious. It relies on showing two screens at once during menus (wasting the vast majority of your screen on black space) and the controller support is horrible. It does not support X-Input, only DirectInput, and the remapping is REALLY bad to the point that the game will outright refuse to detect some axes and buttons, forcing you to rely on external tools such as XPadder.

In general, the game is actually very enjoyable, with amazing gameplay and the musical and visual flair to match. But the boss fights and especially basically everything technical about the port brings the experience so far down that honestly I just don't want to bother with all the hassle. Ultimately, I regret this purchase, but I feel like this game would actually be worth it on a platform where the port doesn't suck ♥♥♥.

I hear there's a sequel being developed. If it makes its way onto Steam, hopefully it can get a proper redesign to support a single screen and actual proper X-Input support as has been a PC standard since a freaking decade ago.

reviewText:
Played the game for about four hours and beat it, minus all the extra goodies it has to offer. Wanted to get through it so I could give my bit on what it was, if it was fun, so on and so forth. So know I've played it, and will be going back later to get the achievements (if possible).

So, Azure Striker Gunvolt. If you've seen snapshots and gameplay of this, it's Megaman ZX with a bit of a twist. Instead of just charging up your buster and firing off either little shots or big shots, it's a much more complex system of tagging enemies with your rounds, then electrifying them. I really don't feel like going into much detail as to how the game works, cause the dash works different, the movements different, there's weapons, upgrades, and gear (oh my!), but the core of this game feels like a Megaman ZX. Honestly, I like that about this game, cause I love the Megaman X series. Part if the reason why I bought it in the first place.

Down to the more sectioned off parts of the game, since I've already spoken of the overall gameplay, lets go to the graphics, sound, story, etc.

Visually, the game is not great, but not normal, either. It's got a flare to it that, again, feels like Megaman ZX. I say this because the game's villans are all transforming people with special powers, a lot like the Megamen in the ZX series. The very world itself feels similar, minus the desert stages that always seem to pop up. Now, while I was more focused on the game itself, the visuals were good. Like, 3.7 out of five good. There are only a few scenes where there's a full blown picture instead of just the sprites doing their thing, which is normal, and there's all sorts of neat places that are shown. Cities, jungles, underwater places. Take note, your character can, and will, drown. Fast. So, nothing to really exemplefy in the art/graphics department. What you see is what you get. If you are an in depth guy about this, I dunno. Message me. Maybe I'll get more in detail, but to me, visuals are a game's accompanyment. Sound was fun. It was an electronic feel, each stage had it's own little theme. I didn't pay much attention to it, either. If anything, I have the main menu's theme in my head. But the sound was just as decent as the visuals, where it wasn't amazing, but it was fun to have around. Normally, I never really listen to the music and just have podcasts and what have you in the background, but I'm glad I did mine this way. Also, the game's voices are (of course) in Japanese. No voice acting, though. Not really. Just little quips here and there. Lastly, the story. Now, I ran through this game extremely fast. I did was, again, focused on the gameplay itself. The characters were fun, and I liked them. For a game where there wasn't a ton of dialogue and everything seemed to be more put into the stage creation and the gameplay, I enjoyed the story to an extent. But it's a lackluster story about super powered people, a guy who finds a girl and goes lone wolf on his organization, but still works for them because he needs the money. After doing the rebel organization's dirty work, his waifu is kidnapped, and he goes to save her. Nothing new or original here, really. If anything, the ending is interesting (though I saw it from a mile away). What the story REALLY did for me was want to come back and play the sequel. I hope it's out, cause I want to play it and finish the game. So, while there was little character development and a lackluster story that's been reused more than fifteen times, I want to play the next game, which I guess is what really matters. I just wanted to see some more character development in general, with both Gunvolt and Joule (his waifu, basically. It's more of just a joke for me). I hope that when I go back to get the rest of the achievements, I'll be able to see some more of that, but I don't think I will. Honestly, this game visually, audibly, and story wise feels like a very well done Indie game. But nothing more, nothing less.

Now, the gameplay itself was fun. While I did fly through the game, I did feel like every stage was it's own place. Every stage had its own couple enemies specific to it, as well as the usual enemies that came along with every stage. The stages themselves had puzzles that didn't feel like it was a difficult task to complete, but a screw up would result in some serious punishment. 99.9% of the time, using your electricity will solve whatever puzzle you're having difficulty with. It's just how you use it that matters. Not only that, but the most interesting thing about it all is the risk and reward of using your ability. In most games, your abilities consquences are null. They don't either exist or matter. In Megaman, if you use your abilities, the most that happens is you deplete your ability gauge. So, there's management, but it's simple. In this game, while you do have to manage your ability gauge, that gauge is also what allows you to reduce damage, but only if you're not using it. It can help you float a bit, it helps with puzzles, etc. and so on. There are enemies that will come after you if you use you ability, and using it can get you hurt, but will damage the enemy as well. This risk/reward does no really exist as prominently in most other Megaman games, and it's what I find interesting about Azure Striker. Now, I understand it's not groundbreaking, but I admit they did it well, and I found it more complex than Megaman, which is just hold down the fire button, fire at enemy while dodging attacks, and repeat. With bosses, there's weaknesses, which don't exist in Azure Striker, just your skill with your ability and whatever gear you so happen to hold. If anything, the gameplay was fun and interesting, and is definitly worth a play through, if only because the game's on sale.

Regardless, I'm probably going to come back to this game and complete everything. Not necessarily replay, since I want to be done with this game, but it was still fun. Give it a shot.

reviewText:
Played the game for about four hours and beat it, minus all the extra goodies it has to offer. Wanted to get through it so I could give my bit on what it was, if it was fun, so on and so forth. So know I've played it, and will be going back later to get the achievements (if possible).

So, Azure Striker Gunvolt. If you've seen snapshots and gameplay of this, it's Megaman ZX with a bit of a twist. Instead of just charging up your buster and firing off either little shots or big shots, it's a much more complex system of tagging enemies with your rounds, then electrifying them. I really don't feel like going into much detail as to how the game works, cause the dash works different, the movements different, there's weapons, upgrades, and gear (oh my!), but the core of this game feels like a Megaman ZX. Honestly, I like that about this game, cause I love the Megaman X series. Part if the reason why I bought it in the first place.

Down to the more sectioned off parts of the game, since I've already spoken of the overall gameplay, lets go to the graphics, sound, story, etc.

Visually, the game is not great, but not normal, either. It's got a flare to it that, again, feels like Megaman ZX. I say this because the game's villans are all transforming people with special powers, a lot like the Megamen in the ZX series. The very world itself feels similar, minus the desert stages that always seem to pop up. Now, while I was more focused on the game itself, the visuals were good. Like, 3.7 out of five good. There are only a few scenes where there's a full blown picture instead of just the sprites doing their thing, which is normal, and there's all sorts of neat places that are shown. Cities, jungles, underwater places. Take note, your character can, and will, drown. Fast. So, nothing to really exemplefy in the art/graphics department. What you see is what you get. If you are an in depth guy about this, I dunno. Message me. Maybe I'll get more in detail, but to me, visuals are a game's accompanyment. Sound was fun. It was an electronic feel, each stage had it's own little theme. I didn't pay much attention to it, either. If anything, I have the main menu's theme in my head. But the sound was just as decent as the visuals, where it wasn't amazing, but it was fun to have around. Normally, I never really listen to the music and just have podcasts and what have you in the background, but I'm glad I did mine this way. Also, the game's voices are (of course) in Japanese. No voice acting, though. Not really. Just little quips here and there. Lastly, the story. Now, I ran through this game extremely fast. I did was, again, focused on the gameplay itself. The characters were fun, and I liked them. For a game where there wasn't a ton of dialogue and everything seemed to be more put into the stage creation and the gameplay, I enjoyed the story to an extent. But it's a lackluster story about super powered people, a guy who finds a girl and goes lone wolf on his organization, but still works for them because he needs the money. After doing the rebel organization's dirty work, his waifu is kidnapped, and he goes to save her. Nothing new or original here, really. If anything, the ending is interesting (though I saw it from a mile away). What the story REALLY did for me was want to come back and play the sequel. I hope it's out, cause I want to play it and finish the game. So, while there was little character development and a lackluster story that's been reused more than fifteen times, I want to play the next game, which I guess is what really matters. I just wanted to see some more character development in general, with both Gunvolt and Joule (his waifu, basically. It's more of just a joke for me). I hope that when I go back to get the rest of the achievements, I'll be able to see some more of that, but I don't think I will. Honestly, this game visually, audibly, and story wise feels like a very well done Indie game. But nothing more, nothing less.

Now, the gameplay itself was fun. While I did fly through the game, I did feel like every stage was it's own place. Every stage had its own couple enemies specific to it, as well as the usual enemies that came along with every stage. The stages themselves had puzzles that didn't feel like it was a difficult task to complete, but a screw up would result in some serious punishment. 99.9% of the time, using your electricity will solve whatever puzzle you're having difficulty with. It's just how you use it that matters. Not only that, but the most interesting thing about it all is the risk and reward of using your ability. In most games, your abilities consquences are null. They don't either exist or matter. In Megaman, if you use your abilities, the most that happens is you deplete your ability gauge. So, there's management, but it's simple. In this game, while you do have to manage your ability gauge, that gauge is also what allows you to reduce damage, but only if you're not using it. It can help you float a bit, it helps with puzzles, etc. and so on. There are enemies that will come after you if you use you ability, and using it can get you hurt, but will damage the enemy as well. This risk/reward does no really exist as prominently in most other Megaman games, and it's what I find interesting about Azure Striker. Now, I understand it's not groundbreaking, but I admit they did it well, and I found it more complex than Megaman, which is just hold down the fire button, fire at enemy while dodging attacks, and repeat. With bosses, there's weaknesses, which don't exist in Azure Striker, just your skill with your ability and whatever gear you so happen to hold. If anything, the gameplay was fun and interesting, and is definitly worth a play through, if only because the game's on sale.

Regardless, I'm probably going to come back to this game and complete everything. Not necessarily replay, since I want to be done with this game, but it was still fun. Give it a shot.

reviewText:
As a player of the original 3DS version of the game, I can say that this game is a really really great port! However, if you do not have a Logitech Xbox 360 style controller, or Xbox 360 Controller for PC, then your game experience will be worse most likely. I tried playing this game with the keyboard, and it is VERY clunky. That is about my only complaint about this game, though! Since I have an Xbox 360 controller for PC, it works perfectly and feels almost as comfortable as the original 3DS game felt.

The textures still look amazing in fullscreen, and the game absolutely shines as it runs in 1080p in 30fps.
I actually think that this game SHOULDN'T run at 60fps. There is a special mood to this game, somewhat cinimatic, that would be ruined if it ran at 60fps. It feels just like an old style game, only BETTER.

The music is astounding and fits the game so well.

The story is amazing for what kind of game this is, too! Great characters, and oh my gosh Joule is so adorable I just want to hug her!

Also, the difficulty of the game was executed perfectly. There are so many different options for playing this game. There isn't a specific difficulty, but rather the difficulty of the game greatly depends on what you have equipped on Gunvolt. This allows a difficulty flexability like no other game has.

This game is a true masterpiece, and it reminds me of the great times I had with Mega Man a long time ago...

Why are you still reading this? Just buy the game. If it was $40 it would still be worth it for such a masterpiece.
